Legal_Issue: Can the Federal Court enforce a foreign arbitral award despite procedural irregularities?
Procedural_Stage: Motion for registration, nunc pro tunc order, and consolidation
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided an affidavit with a true copy of the award but lacked formal certification
Decision_Outcome: Award registered retroactively, original order voided, no consolidation
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with registration requirements
Credibility_Factor: Court found no prejudice or impediment to enforcement
Legal_Rule: Federal Court Rules 327, 329(1), 392(2) Rule 3 mandates securing just determination on merits
Standard_of_Review: Compliance with procedural rules and jurisdictional authority
Procedural_Issue: Prothonotary lacked jurisdiction to register foreign judgments
Grounds_for_Claim: Application refiled before a judge for proper registration
Outcome_on_Merits: Enforcement granted despite lack of formal certification
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Original order declared void, new order issued nunc pro tunc
Review_Standard: Rule-based analysis under Federal Court Rules
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No prejudice caused by procedural deficiency
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavit with true copy of the arbitral award
Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules governing enforcement of foreign awards
Applicant_Challenge: Failure to obtain formal certification of the award
Court_Result: Registration ordered nunc pro tunc, consolidation dismissed without costs
Remedy_Requested: Registration of foreign arbitral award, consolidation of proceedings
Remedy_Sought: Enforcement of foreign arbitral award through registration
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of formal certification in initial filing
Applicable_Process: Motion process under Federal Court Rules
